sanatanadharma.title: Sanatana Dharma — Explore Sanatana Dharma
sanatanadharma.definition: The eternal and universal way of life based on truth, righteousness, and spiritual principles that uphold cosmic order.

etymology.dharma: That which sustains and upholds; moral, ethical, and spiritual law

sanatanadharma.ultimategoal: Moksha – Liberation from the cycle of birth and death through realization of the Self as Brahman.
sanatanadharma.articletitle: Understanding Sanatana Dharma - The Eternal Way of Life
sanatanadharma.article:
Sanatana Dharma is a living spiritual, ethical, and cultural vision that traces its roots to the ancient Indian subcontinent while remaining timeless and universal in its outlook. The phrase Sanatana Dharma literally means the eternal dharma, a term that signals continuity across ages and circumstances rather than strict adherence to a single historical origin. At its core, Sanatana Dharma is not merely a religion in the sense of a fixed creed; it is a comprehensive way of life that includes metaphysics, social ethics, ritual practice, art, science, and a plurality of paths for human flourishing.

Sanatana Dharma rests on several foundational truths. First is the conviction of an underlying unity that pervades apparent diversity. The many names, forms, and philosophies that arise within its scope are seen as varied expressions of a single cosmic reality. Second is the law of karma, the ethical principle that actions have consequences tied to intention and result, shaping present experience and future circumstances. Third is the pursuit of moksha, freedom from the cycle of birth and death, attained through self-realization and inner transformation.

These foundations inform a flexible approach to spiritual life. Sanatana Dharma recognises multiple valid paths to the divine and the highest human good. Bhakti, the path of devotion, emphasizes heartfelt love and surrender to a personal deity; jnana, the path of knowledge, cultivates discriminating wisdom and self-inquiry to reveal the true nature of consciousness; karma, the path of right action, teaches that selfless service and ethical conduct purify mind and heart; and raja yoga or dhyana emphasises discipline of the body and mind through meditative practices. Each path suits different temperaments and stages of life, and many adherents integrate practices from several strands in daily life.

Scriptures in Sanatana Dharma form a rich and layered corpus rather than a single canonical text. The Vedas, often regarded as the oldest layer, provide hymns, rituals, and philosophical seeds that later centuries elaborated. The Upanishads deepen the Vedic insight, focusing on the nature of the Self and ultimate reality. Epic narratives such as the Mahabharata and Ramayana transmit moral teachings, human dilemmas, and exemplars of virtue. The Bhagavad Gita, embedded in the Mahabharata, is a concise guide to living a life of duty, wisdom, and devotion. Puranas, Smritis, and diverse regional literatures expand the cultural and devotional landscape, while classical systems of philosophy — Sankhya, Yoga, Nyaya, Vaisheshika, Mimamsa, and Vedanta — provide systematic frameworks for metaphysics and practice.

Practices in Sanatana Dharma bridge the personal and communal. Rituals range from household rites marking birth, marriage, and death to elaborate temple ceremonies and seasonal observances. Mantras and stotras strengthen concentration and devotion, while puja offers a symbolic exchange of gifts and reverence. Yoga, in its broad classical sense, provides techniques to harmonize body, breath, and mind; pranayama and asana are preparatory tools for deeper concentration and insight. Ethical precepts such as satya (truth), ahimsa (nonviolence), and vrata (disciplined vows) shape conduct within families and communities.

A distinguishing feature of Sanatana Dharma is its pluralism and openness. Rather than insisting on theological uniformity, it often accommodates multiple beliefs and practices. Local customs, regional languages, and cultural arts have been woven into devotional life, making the tradition rich with regional diversity. This adaptability has enabled Sanatana Dharma to evolve over millennia while preserving fundamental principles. Internal critique, reinterpretation by gurus and scholars, and cross-cultural exchange have continually renewed its thought and practice.

Philosophically, Sanatana Dharma invites inquiry into the self, the world, and the ultimate. Nondual schools such as Advaita Vedanta teach that the individual self is identical with the universal Brahman, and liberation is the recognition of that truth. Dualistic and qualified nondual traditions, such as Dvaita and Vishishtadvaita, emphasize a personal relationship with the divine while maintaining rigorous metaphysical distinctions. Buddhism and Jainism developed in the same cultural milieu and shared ethical and soteriological concerns, contributing to a plural and dynamic intellectual environment.

The ethics of Sanatana Dharma emphasize harmony and balance. Moral action is contextual and situation-sensitive rather than purely rule-bound in many classical texts. Dharma involves duties appropriate to ones position and responsibilities, anchored in compassion and social welfare. This moral flexibility has been a strength in addressing complex social situations, but it has also been debated and reinterpreted across time to confront inequalities and injustices.

Sanatana Dharma has inspired a vast cultural heritage. Temple architecture, sculpture, classical music and dance, poetry, and performed epics express spiritual ideas through sensory experience and community involvement. Festivals mark cycles of nature, epochs in the sacred narratives, and the devotion of communities, regenerating shared memory and values. Educational institutions such as ancient gurukulas and modern centres of learning have transmitted scriptural study, logic, and arts across generations.

In modern contexts, Sanatana Dharma continues to matter in multiple ways. First, it remains a living tradition for millions, structuring worship, family life, and communal identity. Second, its philosophical resources contribute to global conversations on consciousness, ecology, and the ethics of technology. Concepts such as interdependence, the sacredness of life, and inner cultivation resonate with contemporary concerns about environmental degradation and mental well-being. Third, its pluralistic ethos can model ways of living with diversity in multicultural societies.

At the same time, modernity has posed challenges. Colonial encounters, nationalist politics, and social reform movements have reshaped how Sanatana Dharma is understood and practiced. Reformers sought to eradicate social ills and reassert humane values, while others emphasized cultural revival. Today, dialogue between tradition and modern values continues — addressing caste-based discrimination, gender equality, and human rights, among other issues. Many contemporary teachers and movements emphasise the universal spiritual core of Sanatana Dharma while actively engaging in social service and ethical reform.

Learning from Sanatana Dharma requires both historical sensitivity and practical humility. Its breadth resists simplistic summaries, and careful study reveals internal diversity as well as shared commitments. For newcomers, it helps to begin with a few accessible practices — simple meditation, ethical reflection, and reading of introductory texts such as the Bhagavad Gita or selected Upanishads — while appreciating the living practices embodied in temples, satsangs, and community gatherings.

Ultimately, Sanatana Dharma invites a life of inner clarity and responsible engagement. Its teachings encourage a shift from identification with transient roles to recognition of deeper identity and duty. Whether one pursues liberation or seeks to live ethically and happily in the world, the tradition offers conceptual tools and practiced disciplines that support meaningful transformation. Its emphasis on interconnectedness, compassion, and the cultivation of wisdom remains a resource not only for personal growth but also for building societies that honor dignity, diversity, and the sacredness of life.

slides.subtitle: `I bow to Lord Ganesha.` The remover of obstacles, patron of wisdom, prosperity, and auspicious beginnings.
`I bow to Parvati.` The divine mother goddess, symbolizing love, fertility, and devotion.
`I bow to Lord Murugan.` The god of war and victory, known for his courage, strength, and wisdom.
`I bow to Shiva.` The simplest and most powerful mantra for inner peace, purification, and spiritual awakening.
`I bow to Lord Vasudeva (Krishna).` A powerful mantra for devotion, protection, and spiritual growth.

slides.sankrittitle: श्री राम जय राम जय जय राम
slides.englishtitle: (Shri Rama Jaya Rama Jaya Jaya Rama)
slides.subtitle: `Glory to Rama, Victory to Rama, All victory to Rama.` This is the famous *Tarak Mantra* (Liberation Mantra), chanted for **Moksha**, inner peace, and divine protection.

slides.sankrittitle: हरे राम हरे राम राम राम हरे हरे। हरे कृष्ण हरे कृष्ण कृष्ण कृष्ण हरे हरे॥
slides.englishtitle: (Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare. Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare.)
slides.subtitle: `O Energy of the Lord, O Rama, O Krishna, please engage me in Your devotional service.` This Mahamantra is chanted for **spiritual liberation (Moksha), cleansing the mind of distress, and experiencing divine ecstasy and bliss.**
`I bow to Saraswati.` The goddess of knowledge, music, arts, and wisdom.
`I bow to Hanuman.` The simple and potent Moola Mantra invoking courage, strength, wisdom, and protection from all dangers.

heading: ॐ भूर्भुवः स्वः
तत् सवितुर्वरेण्यम्
भर्गो देवस्य धीमहि
धियो यो नः प्रचोदयात्
gayathri.transliteration: Om Bhur Bhuvah Svah Tat Savitur Varenyam Bhargo Devasya Dheemahi Dhiyo Yo Nah Prachodayat
gayathri.translation: We meditate upon the desirable effulgence of the divine Sun, the impeller. May he stimulate our intellects.

sections1.fastdatatitle: Mantra: Na mah Shivaya. Mantra: Om Tatpurushaya Vidmahe Mahadevaya Dheemahi Tanno Rudrah Prachodayaat
sections1.fastdatadesc: Na mah Shivaya meaning: The five sacred syllables representing Shiva. Om Tatpurushaya meaning: Meditation on Lord Rudra for wisdom and strength.
sections1.trendstitle: Mantra: Om Namo Naraayanaya. Mantra: Om Narayanaya Vidmahe Vasudevaya Dheemahi Tanno Vishnuh Prachodayaat
sections1.trendsdesc: Om Namo Naraayanaya meaning: I bow to Lord Narayana (Vishnu). Om Narayanaya Vidmahe meaning: Meditation on Lord Vishnu for wisdom and guidance.
sections1.adaptyxtitle: The Saṅkṣepa Rāmāyaṇa (also called Śataśloki Rāmāyaṇa).
sections1.adaptyxdesc: Vālmīki asks Nārada: “Who is the greatest person in the world, endowed with all virtues?” Nārada replies by describing Śrī Rāma’s qualities and narrates the entire Ramayana in condensed form. These 100 ślokas are known as Saṅkṣepa Rāmāyaṇa and are often chanted daily or on special occasions like Rama Navami.
sections1.adaptyxprobedesc: Opening ślokas: Vālmīki’s questions about the ideal man. Nārada’s reply: Describes Rāma’s virtues (guṇas) and narrates his life: Birth in Ikṣvāku dynasty Marriage to Sītā Exile for 14 years Abduction of Sītā by Rāvaṇa Alliance with Sugrīva and Hanuman War with Rāvaṇa and victory Coronation and righteous rule Ends with Phalaśruti (benefits of chanting).

heading: ॐ त्र्यम्बकं यजामहे
सुगन्धिं पुष्टिवर्धनम्।
उर्वारुकमिव बन्धनान्
मृत्योर्मुक्षीय माऽमृतात्॥
shiva.transliteration: Oṃ tryambakaṃ yajāmahe sugandhiṃ puṣṭi-vardhanam | Urvarukam iva bandhanān mṛtyor mukṣīya māmṛtāt ||

heading: शान्ताकारम् भुजगशयनम् पद्मनाभम् सुरेशम्।
विश्वाधारम् गगनसदृशम् मेघवर्णम् शुभाङ्गम्।
लक्ष्मीकान्तम् कमलनयनम् योगिभिर्ध्यानगम्यम्।
वन्दे विष्णुम् भवभयहरम् सर्वलोकैकनाथम्॥
krishnabg.transliteration: I bow to Vishnu—Who has a peaceful demeanor (Shanta-karam)...

title: यदा यदा हि
धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत ।
अभ्युत्थानम धर्मस्य
तदात्मानं सृजाम्यहम् ॥
krishnastotram.transliteration: Yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānirbhavati bhārata, Abhyutthāna madharmasya tadātmānaṁ sṛjāmyaham.
krishnastotram.translation: Whenever and wherever there is a decline in righteousness (Dharma), O descendant of Bharata (Arjuna), and a predominance of unrighteousness (Adharma)—at that time I manifest Myself (take birth).
